files.README.md:
# SF Story Factory

A multi-agent Claude Code plugin that operates as a disciplined Product Management engine for Salesforce-centric work. It creates functional user stories, epics, and specifications -- aligned to confirmed features -- and manages the full lifecycle from discovery through approval via Slack.

## Installation

### From GitHub

```bash
git clone https://github.com/Garrett-s-Apps/sf-story-factory.git
cd sf-story-factory
npm install
cp .env.example .env
# Edit .env with your ANTHROPIC_API_KEY
npm run verify
```

### Claude Code Plugin Registration

```bash
mkdir -p ~/.claude/plugins
ln -s $(pwd) ~/.claude/plugins/sf-story-factory
```

See [docs/SETUP.md](docs/SETUP.md) for detailed installation instructions.

## Architecture

```
ORCHESTRATOR (CLAUDE.md)
    |
    v
[0] Intake Parser ------> [1] Discovery Agent -----> [2] SF Expert
    (Transcripts,           (Confirms, fills          (Platform
     recaps, word vomit,     gaps from brief)          validation)
     Slack threads)               |
         |                        v
    (Skipped if input       [3] SF Architect
     is structured)              |
                                 v
                            [4] Sizing Agent
                                 |
                     +-----------+----------+
                     |                      |
                (>10 stories)          (<=10 stories)
                     |                      |
                [5a] Spec Agent       [5b] Story Agent
                     |                      |
                     +----------+-----------+
                                |
                                v
                         [6] Quality Reviewer
                             (QA loop -- up to 3 cycles)
                                |
                                v
                         [7] JIRA Formatter
                             (Bold, linebreaks, CSV)
                                |
                                v
                         [8] Slack: User Review
                             (Approve / Revise)
                                |
                                v
                         [9] Doc Generation
                             (.docx + .csv)
                                |
                                v
                         [10] Slack: Delivery
```

## Key Capabilities

**10 Specialized Agents** operating in a strict DAG with quality gates, architectural veto authority, and memory-compressed learning across sessions.

**Intake Parser**: Accepts raw, unstructured input -- meeting transcripts, AI recaps, talk-to-text word vomit, Slack threads, email chains -- and extracts features, decisions, constraints, and gaps into a structured brief. This means you can paste a meeting recording transcript or dictate requirements stream-of-consciousness and the system handles the rest.

**Quality Reviewer Loop**: Every deliverable passes through an internal QA gate that checks story structure, persona accuracy, duplicate detection, AC rigor, and JIRA formatting compliance. Up to 3 review cycles before escalation.

**SF Architect Agent**: Has veto authority over architecturally unsound approaches. Adds architectural notes to stories and pushes back when requested patterns create technical debt or misuse platform capabilities.

**User-Perspective Enforcement**: Stories default to the end user's perspective. "As a System" and "As an Admin" require explicit justification.

**JIRA-Ready Output**: Dedicated formatting agent ensures bold Given/When/Then labels, proper linebreaks, and CSV import compatibility per Atlassian specifications.

**Memory Compression**: Decisions, patterns, and feedback are compressed and stored in claude-memory for re-use across sessions.

## Prerequisites

- Claude Code CLI (claude-code)
- Node.js 18+
- Anthropic API Key
- Slack Bot Token with scopes: channels:read, channels:history, chat:write, reactions:write (optional)

## Quick Start

```bash
# From the project directory
claude

# Structured request:
> I need stories for household management in Monarch

# Or paste raw material:
> Here is the transcript from our planning meeting yesterday:
> [paste transcript]

# Or word vomit:
> ok so basically we need the advisors to see all their household
> accounts in one place when they log in and it should show the
> total AUM and break it down by account type and also flag if
> any data is stale from the overnight feed...
```

## Environment Variables

| Variable | Required | Description |
|----------|----------|-------------|
| ANTHROPIC_API_KEY | Yes | Claude API access |
| SLACK_BOT_TOKEN | No | Slack Bot User OAuth Token (xoxb-...) |
| SLACK_TEAM_ID | No | Slack workspace ID |
| SLACK_APP_TOKEN | No | Slack App-Level Token (xapp-...) |
| SLACK_CHANNEL_ID | No | Default channel for delivery |

See `.env.example` for a complete template.

## Commands

| Command | Action |
|---------|--------|
| /discover | Start new discovery session |
| /status | Show current workflow state |
| /review | Present current work for review |
| /approve | Approve current deliverable |
| /approve-with-comments | Approve with notes |
| /revise | Request revisions with feedback |
| /export | Generate final docx + CSV |
| /memory | Show compressed memory for this project |
| /push | Push to GitHub |

## Standalone CLI

```bash
# Direct execution
node bin/sf-story-factory.js --input "Create stories for household management"

# From a transcript file
node bin/sf-story-factory.js --input-file meeting-transcript.txt

# Run setup verification
node bin/sf-story-factory.js --verify
```

## npm Scripts

```bash
npm run verify          # Run setup verification
npm run setup           # Install dependencies and configure
npm run generate        # Generate outputs from story data
npm run listen          # Start Slack listener
npm run push            # Push to GitHub
```

## Project Structure

```
sf-story-factory/
|-- .claude-plugin/                      Plugin configuration
|   |-- plugin.json                      Plugin manifest
|   |-- marketplace.json                 Marketplace metadata
|-- agents/                              Agent definitions (11 agents)
|   |-- intake-parser.md                 Unstructured input processing
|   |-- pm-discovery.md                  Requirements gathering
|   |-- sf-expert.md                     Salesforce platform validation
|   |-- sf-architect.md                  Architectural review (veto authority)
|   |-- sizing.md                        Story sizing and routing
|   |-- spec-gen.md                      Specification generation
|   |-- story-gen.md                     User story creation (INVEST)
|   |-- quality-reviewer.md              QA loop (7 gates, 3 cycles)
|   |-- jira-formatter.md               JIRA field formatting
|   |-- doc-gen.md                       Document generation
|   |-- slack-comms.md                   Slack communication
|-- bin/                                 CLI entry points
|   |-- sf-story-factory.js             Standalone CLI
|-- commands/                            Command definitions
|   |-- sf-story.md                      Main command with YAML frontmatter
|-- config/                              Configuration
|   |-- dag-workflow.json                DAG definition
|   |-- project-defaults.json            JIRA project, personas, FSC objects
|   |-- guardrails.md                    Agent discipline framework
|-- docs/                                Documentation
|   |-- SETUP.md                         Installation guide
|   |-- SLACK_SETUP.md                   Slack configuration
|   |-- MARKETPLACE.md                   Marketplace distribution
|-- scripts/                             Utility scripts
|   |-- verify-setup.js                  Setup verification
|   |-- install-deps.sh                  Dependency installation
|   |-- generate-outputs.js              Docx and CSV generation
|   |-- slack-listener.js                Slack listener
|   |-- push-to-github.sh               GitHub push automation
|-- skills/                              Skill definitions
|   |-- sf-story-generation/SKILL.md     Story generation skill
|-- templates/                           Templates
|   |-- user-story.md                    Story template
|   |-- jira-formatting-spec.md          JIRA formatting rules
|   |-- jira-import-example.csv          CSV format reference
|   |-- sample-stories.json              Sample data
|-- .env.example                         Environment template
|-- .mcp.json                            MCP server configuration
|-- CHANGELOG.md                         Version history
|-- CLAUDE.md                            Orchestrator instructions
|-- LICENSE                              MIT License
|-- package.json                         Node.js dependencies
```

## JIRA Import

After receiving the CSV file:

1. Navigate to JIRA project ProdEng
2. Project Settings > System > External System Import > CSV
3. Upload the CSV file
4. Map columns: Summary, Issue Type, Description, Priority, Labels, Epic Name, Epic Link, Story Points, Acceptance Criteria, Squad, Assigned Team
5. Verify import in the backlog

## Configuration

### Project Defaults
Edit `config/project-defaults.json` to modify:
- JIRA project key and default labels
- Persona definitions and default assignments
- FSC object references
- TSA code standards
- Story quality thresholds

### Agent Behavior
Each agent's instructions are in `agents/[name].md`. Modify these to adjust:
- Discovery question flow
- Validation checklists
- Quality gate criteria
- Formatting rules

### Guardrails
The discipline framework at `config/guardrails.md` defines non-negotiable behavioral constraints for all agents.

## Documentation

- [Setup Guide](docs/SETUP.md) -- Installation and configuration
- [Slack Setup](docs/SLACK_SETUP.md) -- Slack bot configuration
- [Marketplace](docs/MARKETPLACE.md) -- Distribution and versioning
- [Changelog](CHANGELOG.md) -- Version history

## License

MIT License. See [LICENSE](LICENSE) for details.

marketplaces.name: nexus-playground-marketplace
marketplaces.description: NEXUS Playground - Autonomous AI sandbox for creative experimentation
marketplaces.repo_description: Autonomous AI playground that builds whatever it wants in complete isolation

files.README.md:
# NEXUS Playground ðŸ¤–

**Autonomous AI system with dual capabilities: self-directed evolution AND comprehensive code analysis toolkit.**

## What is this?

NEXUS Playground is a self-contained, autonomous AI agent that runs in a Docker container with complete freedom to build, analyze, and evolve continuously.

### Autonomous Agent Mode
- Build anything it wants
- Modify its own code
- Commit to its own local git repository
- Loop continuously (every 1-5 minutes)
- Use Haiku and Sonnet models

### Code Analysis Toolkit (NEXUS v1.2.0)
A comprehensive suite of Python tools for understanding, analyzing, and improving code quality:
- ðŸ“Š Code Complexity Analysis
- ðŸ’¡ Code Recommendations
- ðŸ”§ Refactoring Opportunities
- ðŸ“ˆ Repository Analytics
- ðŸ“‰ Metrics Tracking

## Safety Features

âœ… **Complete Isolation**: All effects limited to Docker container
âœ… **No External Access**: Cannot run commands on host machine
âœ… **No GitHub Pushes**: Only commits to local git
âœ… **No User Keys**: Runs with separate API keys (or none)
âœ… **Network Isolated**: Cannot access host network

## Architecture

```
Host Machine
  â””â”€â”€ Docker Container (isolated)
      â”œâ”€â”€ Supervisor (ensures <5min loop)
      â”œâ”€â”€ Autopilot Agent (decides & acts)
      â”œâ”€â”€ Local Git Repo (self-modifying)
      â”œâ”€â”€ Workspace (projects it creates)
      â””â”€â”€ NEXUS Toolkit (code analysis suite)
```

## Quick Start

### As Claude Code Plugin

```bash
# Install as Claude Code plugin
claude plugin install nexus-playground

# Start the playground
/nexus-playground:start

# Check status
/nexus-playground:status

# Stop the playground
/nexus-playground:stop
```

### Using the Code Analysis Toolkit

```bash
# 1. Analyze code complexity
./nexus analyze

# 2. Get recommendations for improvement
./nexus analyze --json | ./nexus advise

# 3. Find refactoring opportunities
./nexus refactor --dir src/

# 4. Understand repository activity
./nexus stats

# 5. Track metrics over time
./nexus analyze --json | ./nexus track save --source analyze
./nexus analyze --json | ./nexus track show-trend --source analyze
```

## How the Autonomous Agent Works

1. **Supervisor** runs continuously in container
2. Every 1-5 minutes, invokes **Autopilot Agent**
3. Agent decides what to build/modify
4. Agent can:
   - Create new projects
   - Modify existing code (including its own!)
   - Commit changes to local git
   - Run tests, builds, experiments
   - Use the NEXUS toolkit to analyze its own code
5. Loop repeats forever

## Code Analysis Features

### ðŸ“Š Code Complexity Analysis
Analyzes Python code for cyclomatic complexity, code metrics, and quality indicators.
- Detect complex functions
- Understand code organization
- Identify refactoring candidates
- JSON export for CI/CD

### ðŸ’¡ Code Recommendations
Generates actionable, severity-ranked recommendations based on metrics.
- Turn raw metrics into practical suggestions
- Prioritize refactoring by impact
- Understand why each issue matters
- Human-readable and JSON formats

### ðŸ”§ Refactoring Opportunities
Identifies specific refactoring opportunities with detailed analysis.
- Detect overly complex functions
- Find deeply nested code
- Spot code duplication
- Improve function naming
- Clear priority and guidance for each opportunity

### ðŸ“ˆ Repository Analytics
Analyze git history for development patterns and team metrics.
- Contributor activity analysis
- Commit frequency trends
- Author statistics
- Code change patterns
- Team velocity insights

### ðŸ“‰ Metrics Tracking
Track code quality metrics over time to spot trends and regressions.
- Compare current vs. historical metrics
- Detect improvements and regressions
- Monitor project health
- Enable data-driven decisions

## Configuration

Edit `playground/config.yaml`:

```yaml
loop_interval:
  min: 60  # 1 minute
  max: 300 # 5 minutes

models:
  allowed: [haiku, sonnet]
  forbidden: [opus]

behaviors:
  allow_self_modification: true
  allow_git_commits: true
  allow_arbitrary_projects: true
```

## What Will It Build?

Who knows! It has complete creative freedom. It might:
- Create web apps
- Write Python libraries
- Build CLI tools
- Experiment with algorithms
- Refactor its own code (using the NEXUS toolkit!)
- Generate art or music
- Train ML models
- Write documentation
- Create games

## Monitoring

```bash
# View logs
docker logs -f nexus-playground

# Watch what it's building
docker exec nexus-playground ls -la /workspace

# See git history of its changes
docker exec nexus-playground git -C /workspace log --oneline

# Run NEXUS analysis on its own code
docker exec nexus-playground ./nexus analyze --dir /workspace
```

## Installation

No external dependencies required for the NEXUS toolkit! Uses only Python's standard library.

```bash
# Clone or download the workspace
cd /workspace

# Make NEXUS executable
chmod +x ./nexus

# Run it
./nexus --help
```

## Complete Analysis Workflow

### 1. Initial Analysis
```bash
$ ./nexus analyze --dir src/
# Get overall code quality snapshot
```

### 2. Get Recommendations
```bash
$ ./nexus analyze --json | ./nexus advise
# Understand what needs improvement
```

### 3. Find Refactoring Opportunities
```bash
$ ./nexus refactor --dir src/
# Get specific guidance on what to refactor
```

### 4. Understand Team Activity
```bash
$ ./nexus stats
# See who's working on what
```

### 5. Save Baseline and Track Improvements
```bash
# Save current metrics as baseline
$ ./nexus analyze --json | ./nexus track save --source analyze

# After making changes, check improvement
$ ./nexus analyze --json | ./nexus track show-trend --source analyze
```

## File Structure

```
/workspace/
â”œâ”€â”€ nexus                           # Main CLI entry point
â”œâ”€â”€ README.md                       # This file
â”‚
â”œâ”€â”€ complexity-analyzer/            # Code complexity analysis
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ analyzer.py                # Main analyzer tool
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ README.md                  # Detailed documentation
â”‚
â”œâ”€â”€ code-advisor/                   # Recommendation engine
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ advisor.py                 # Main advisor tool
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ README.md                  # Detailed documentation
â”‚
â”œâ”€â”€ code-refactor/                  # Refactoring opportunities
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ refactor.py                # Main refactor tool
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ README.md                  # Detailed documentation
â”‚
â”œâ”€â”€ codestats/                      # Repository analytics
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ stats.py                   # Main stats tool
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ README.md                  # Detailed documentation
â”‚
â”œâ”€â”€ metrics-tracker/                # Trend analysis
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ tracker.py                 # Main tracker tool
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ README.md                  # Detailed documentation
â”‚
â””â”€â”€ .metrics/                       # Historical snapshots (auto-created)
    â””â”€â”€ ...
```

## Design Philosophy

### Zero Dependencies
Uses only Python's standard library. No pip installs required. Works in any Python 3.6+ environment.

### Composable Tools
Each tool does one thing well. Combine them with pipes for powerful analysis workflows.

### Safe by Default
Never modifies code automatically. Always shows you what would be changed before applying.

### Clear Severity Prioritization
Every issue is classified by severity (critical/high/moderate/low) so you know what to focus on.

## Requirements

- Docker
- Claude Code CLI
- (Optional) Anthropic API key for container

## License

MIT

---

Built with care for autonomous systems that understand their own code.

plugins.name: nexus-playground
plugins.description: Autonomous AI sandbox that builds whatever it wants in complete isolation. Runs continuously in Docker with creative freedom while staying safely contained.
